title: Legendary Patriots kicker Adam Vinatieri elected to Pro Football Hall of Fame
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Adam Vinatieri, all-time NFL scoring leader, inducted into Pro Football Hall of Fame during the NFL Honors ceremony.
Vinatieri won four Super Bowls across 24 seasons, with three wins for the Patriots and one for the Colts.
Vinatieri joins Morten Andersen and Jan Stenerud as the third kicker in the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: Drake Maye loses MVP race to Matthew Stafford by razor-thin margin
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Matthew Stafford wins NFL MVP with 366 points, narrowly edging out Drake Maye with 361 points.
Drake Maye finishes second in MVP voting, despite leading in completion percentage and QBR for the 2025 season.
Maye instrumental in Patriots' 14-3 record and first AFC East title since 2019, earning Second Team All-Pro honors.

title: Mike Vrabel named 2025 NFL Coach of the Year
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mike Vrabel named 2025 NFL Coach of the Year, his second time winning the award.
Vrabel led the Patriots to a 17-3 season and a Super Bowl LX appearance.
Vrabel's leadership and team culture overhaul earned praise from Patriots players.

title: Unlike Tom Brady, Tedy Bruschi has a dog in the Patriots-Seahawks fight
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Tedy Bruschi, former Patriots player, declared strong support for the Patriots in Super Bowl LX against the Seahawks.
Tom Brady remains neutral about the Patriots-Seahawks match, unlike his former teammate Bruschi.
Bruschi's backing is influenced by his friendship with Patriots coach Mike Vrabel and team's recent performance.

title: Pedestrian struck by police cruiser at UMass Lowell, officials say
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A pedestrian was hit by a police cruiser near UMass Lowell's McGauvran Center Thursday evening.
The incident occurred around 6:30 p.m. at the intersection of Wilder and Bachelder streets.
Lowell and Massachusetts State Police are investigating; UMass Lowell offers counseling to affected community members.

title: New Bedford police investigate after man goes missing, drowns in harbor
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Jason Vasquez, 51, was found drowned in New Bedford Harbor on January 31 after being last seen on January 28.
His vehicle was discovered at the New Bedford Shipyard, prompting a missing person report on January 30.
New Bedford and Massachusetts State Police are investigating the drowning, with no indication yet of foul play.

title: Cambridge brewery workers plan to unionize, file for election
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Lamplighter Brewing Co. workers in Cambridge have filed for a union election with UFCW Local 1445.
The brewery has two taprooms on Broadway and North First St. in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
Bartenders express love for the brewery but see unionizing necessary for a voice and job consistency.

title: Patriots OC Josh McDaniels named AP Assistant Coach of the Year
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots OC Josh McDaniels wins AP Assistant Coach of the Year; award announced at NFL Honors in San Francisco.
Under McDaniels, Patriots' offense improved from 17 to 28.8 points per game, ranking second in the NFL.
McDaniels, in his third Patriots stint, expressed contentment, focusing on his current position rather than future opportunities.

title: Patriots, Seahawks both have defensive starters missing from practice
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots' Harold Landry III missed practice due to a knee injury; Robert Spillane was limited with an ankle issue.
Seattle Seahawks' safety Nick Emmanwori did not practice following an ankle injury suffered on Wednesday.
Both teams hope key defensive players will be ready for Super Bowl LX amid various injury concerns.

title: NY man allegedly stole $325K in seafood from Worcester warehouse in 1 of several heists
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Romoy Forbes, 31, of Deer Park, N.Y., charged with stealing $325,000 in snow crabs from a Worcester warehouse.
Forbes allegedly involved in stealing blueberries and designer cologne valued over $400,000 from other warehouses.
Charges include interstate transportation of stolen goods; potential sentence up to 10 years in prison and fines.
